post_text: Masks, sanitizing, sick rooms, distance dots and water fountains???? The changes and expectations can be scary and overwhelming at times. Our nursing staff created a short video that is full of helpful information about what to expect when our schools welcome back our students next week. Please take a few minutes to watch with your child to help lessen any anxiety as we ease into our school year. We can't wait for the sounds and faces of our kids to fill our halls again! We will see you soon!

Masks, sanitizing, sick rooms, distance dots and water fountains???? The changes and expectations can be scary and overwhelming at times. Our nursing staff created a short video that is full of helpful information about what to expect when our schools welcome back our students next week. Please take a few minutes to watch with your child to help lessen any anxiety as we ease into our school year. We can't wait for the sounds and faces of our kids to fill our halls again! We will see you soon!

post_text:
Some of our schools start registration this coming week. Schoology is our Learning Management System for communication and instructional content. As a parent or guardian, you are encouraged to get an account. It will become our main source of disseminating information. It is free for all parents and guardians of enrolled students and there‚Äôs an app for it. If you don‚Äôt have an account already, ask for a Schoology code at registration. You can find a link on our District homepage on the upper left of the screen. It is loaded with ‚ÄúHow To‚Äù and features‚Äô information.

https://www.lowndes.k12.ms.us

post_text:
Greetings parents and guardians of LCSD,
We know you are anxiously awaiting our Back to School plan for 2020-2021 and we are fine tuning the details. Your patience and understanding is very much appreciated as we are examining every facet of each detail. We plan to release our plan Friday afternoon. The tentative start date is August 6 for students, pending board approval. Thank you!
text:
Greetings parents and guardians of LCSD,
We know you are anxiously awaiting our Back to School plan for 2020-2021 and we are fine tuning the details. Your patience and understanding is very much appreciated as we are examining every facet of each detail. We plan to release our plan Friday afternoon. The tentative start date is August 6 for students, pending board approval. Thank you!

post_text:
The LCSD Central Office has been closed until June 11, 2020. Please submit your Pre-K applications by June 11, 2020, to the school of your residence on Monday-Thursday between the hours of 8:00am and 2:00pm. The applications will be held at the school until the Central Office resumes regular hours. You will be notified as to when and where to bring your child for screening.
Thank you for your patience!
text:
The LCSD Central Office has been closed until June 11, 2020. The applications will be held at the school until the Central Office resumes regular hours. You will be notified as to when and where to bring your child for screening.
Thank you for your patience!

post_text: The news of no more school for this school year has reverberated across Mississippi this afternoon. The Governor has decided to keep our schools empty so that Corona can go about its merry way. We will give Corona the space it needs but only in the name of safety for our most precious gifts. Time heals all wounds but this one has cut deeply into our teacher hearts and we are not ok. Please stay tuned for further updates. (Please no negative comments)

post_text:
The screening that was scheduled for the Title I Pre-K Program will be delayed until further notification. If you submitted an application for this program, you will be contacted by phone for a screening appointment date and time when school resumes.

The Title I Pre-K application deadline will be extended. A new due date will be determined when school resumes.

If your child was scheduled for MERIT testing on one of the scheduled Saturdays, this testing will be rescheduled at a later date. You will be contacted when school resumes to reschedule.
text:
The screening that was scheduled for the Title I Pre-K Program will be delayed until further notification. If you submitted an application for this program, you will be contacted by phone for a screening appointment date and time when school resumes.

The Title I Pre-K application deadline will be extended. A new due date will be determined when school resumes.

If your child was scheduled for MERIT testing on one of the scheduled Saturdays, this testing will be rescheduled at a later date. You will be contacted when school resumes to reschedule.

Parents and Guardians,
The Governor has closed all schools in the state until April 17. We will continue to provide learning materials and lessons throughout this time. Please log in to Schoology to get assignments that have been posted by your teachers. Students in grades k-4 need to go to schoology.com not the lowndes.schoology.com website.

If you need Schoology help email Hope (hope.elliott@lowndes.k12.ms.us); she‚Äôs glad to assist.

post_text:
From James Spann‚Äî(yes! THE Spann Man)

Yo moms and dads with kids at home (that would normally be at school)... I will be doing an online, live weather program Thursday morning at 10:00 a.m. CT. it is fun, interactive, and best for kids grades 1-5, but older kids (and adults) should enjoy it as well. Learn more about the science of meteorology, how we forecast weather, severe thunderstorms, hurricanes, tornadoes, and snow storms. You will learn and have a few laughs, and we all could use that now.

So, get it on your calendar... this Thursday at 10a CT. It will be streamed live here on this Facebook page. Be sure it is the James Spann page with the blue check (verified).

To help educators during this time of coronavirus, we have pulled our most popular science lessons and are offering them for anyone to use for free. No account or login is needed. Go to the link below and check them out. Mystery Science is the creator of the most popular science lessons in U.S. schools.

All of the lessons below are expertly designed to engage students, achieve learning outcomes, and be easy to use. They have short mini-lessons that are completely digital and full lessons that include an activity. All of the activities are designed to use simple supplies a parent will likely already have at home.

Lessons for: Kindergarten | 1st Grade | 2nd Grade | 3rd Grade | 4th Grade | 5th Grade

post_text:
‚ÄúThe public educational company Scholastic came up with a way to keep kids busy and learning while school closures keep them home during coronavirus pandemic.

Scholastic set up a ‚ÄòLearn From Home‚Äô website with four categories: PreK and Kindergarten, Grades 1 and 2, Grades 3-5, and Grades 6+. Each section is already equipped with one week of content for students with 15 additional days on the way.

Each day of content is filled with exciting articles and stories, videos, and fun learning challenges. The students can even go on virtual field trips or meet best-selling authors.

The website provides up to three hours‚Äô worth of content each day and can be completed on any device.‚Äù
Click on the website below and then follow the links for the appropriate grade level.
shared_text:
CLASSROOMMAGAZINES.SCHOLASTIC.COM
Teaching Remotely for Grades K - 12 | Free Resources and Strategies

post_text:
The Lowndes County School District has decided it is in the best interest for our students and staff to cancel school on Monday and Tuesday in order to gather more information and seek guidance moving forward concerning COVID-19. I genuinely hope we look back on this decision as an overreaction. The main issue driving this decision is that so many of our students and staff traveled over the break. We feel these two days will help us relay the best information of who could possibly be at risk of infection and who needs to remain home and for how long. There is so much unknown concerning the United States and COVID-19, but the virus is having devastating effects on many countries around the world. We want to do everything we can to prevent that type of outbreak. Please be patient with us as we gather information and make the best decisions for our community moving forward.

Sam Allison
Superintendent
text:

We feel these two days will help us relay the best information of who could possibly be at risk of infection and who needs to remain home and for how long. There is so much unknown concerning the United States and COVID-19, but the virus is having devastating effects on many countries around the world. We want to do everything we can to prevent that type of outbreak. Please be patient with us as we gather information and make the best decisions for our community moving forward.

Sam Allison

post_text: The NHMS Robotics team participated in the Turkey Towers VEX Competition in Saltillo Saturday against 17 other high school and middle school teams. All six NHMS teams made it to the alliance selection round of 16. Two teams ended up in the final round. Team B, Hayden Wofford and Hayes Moody, and Team C, Brady Hogan, Thomas Oglesby, and Joshua Wilcox, were on opposing sides. Team C ended up victorious. Team C was also the Skills Champion! Way to go NHMS Robotics Crew!

post_text: Yesterday these New Hope Middle Robotics Students competed in their first tournament! Out of 18 teams at our Career Tech‚Äôs Fall Fiasco, 13 were high school teams, AND three of our teams were in the championship match. Team G: Keona Montague, Aubri Stacy and Joshua Tate and Team D: Hayes Moody, Koen Richardson and Ash Taylor, are tournament champions and already qualified for the MS State Tournament! All of our teams did an AMAZING job! Thanks to our folks at the CTC for hosting this event and opportunity for students.

All emergency procedures were followed and school has now been returned to the regular schedule. Thank you for your patience and cooperation.

post_text:
Alright LCSD friends and supporters, we are still pretty ‚Äúover the moon‚Äù with our A-rating and so, as a result, we are going to brag for probably most of the year. It really is a big deal with only 31 ‚ÄúA‚Äù districts in the state (out of 145). Our state tests measure each student‚Äôs score compared to his or her previous year and how well they did on the new content. This ‚ÄúA‚Äù is a celebration of every student in every school who scored better than the year before and every teacher who taught like their hair was on üî•!!! The map shows where the ‚ÄúA‚Äù districts are located around the state.

(We know there is so much more that happens in a school day and school year than state tests.)

post_text: Welcome to 2019-2020! Traffic WILL BE rough for the first couple of weeks but it seems to to settle down once everyone gets in the groove. Our school offices will be busy, busy places, so your patience is greatly appreciated as we work to meet everyone's needs. If you are new to our district (and there are many of you), WELCOME!!! We trust that your school experience is stellar in each and every way! Please let us know how we can help, whenever needed.

We trust that your school experience is stellar in each and every way! Please let us know how we can help, whenever needed.

post_text:
Tomorrow is the big day (and Election Day)

Safety Tips for Motorists When Sharing the Road with "The Big Yellow Cheese" (<---joke--we love and appreciate our drivers and fleet!!‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è)

--Pay attention to the bus's flashing warning lights and mechanical "stop sign arm."
--Make a complete stop when the bus's warning lights are flashing, or the stop sign arm comes out. Do not proceed until the arm is lowered and the lights stop flashing.
--Lower your driving speed around schools and especially where children are loading and unloading from buses and cars.
--Share the road with the yellow bus.
--Obey the School Zone speed limit of 15 mph when school is in session and children are present.

post_text: On Tuesday our rooms will be filled with students and our halls will echo the sweet sounds of the start-of-school hustle. Friday we kicked off the start of the year with our Back to School convocation. Many thanks to Dr. Parker, MUW President Nora Miller, Lt. Col. Richardson and Maj. Ludington whose stories and messages inspired us. A huge shout out to Educators are Essential who always rally our teachers! The ringing of the first bell on Tuesday will also be Election Day, so the traffic might be extra-extra!

post_text:
MSU will be partnering with Mississippi Construction Education Foundation (MCEF) this summer to provide students of the Golden Triangle the opportunity to attend a construction camp. This will be the first year it has been offered, and they hope to make it an annual event. It‚Äôs available to students who are going into the8th-12th grade. Students will be able to stay on campus while learning hands on construction techniques and participate in other fun activities.

Here is a link for more information and registration:
http://mcef.net/2019-building-futures-camp/

Scholarships for the camp are available. For those interested, please contact the director of the MSU Building Construction Science program, George Ford at gford@caad.msstate.edu or 662-325-8310.
